articles.headline: Bill on Finance Wins Approval of Senate Panel
articles.snippet: Republicans said that they had forced Democrats back to the bargaining table, but Democrats said that Republicans were hastily abandoning their opposition to the plan.
articles.abstract: Republicans said that they had forced Democrats back to the bargaining table, but Democrats said that Republicans were hastily abandoning their opposition to the plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans and Democrats predicted on Wednesday that Congress would soon pass a far-reaching overhaul of the nation’s financial regulatory system, indicating a potentially swift resolution of the latest partisan firefight on Capitol Hill.
articles.byline: By Edward Wyatt and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: U.S. Offers a Hand to Those on Eviction’s Edge
articles.snippet: Without government aid, economists say many formerly middle-class Americans are at risk of slipping into poverty, even as economic conditions improve.
articles.abstract: Without government aid, economists say many formerly middle-class Americans are at risk of slipping into poverty, even as economic conditions improve.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN MATEO, Calif. — Two years into a merciless downward spiral, Antonio Moore was threatened with living on the street.

articles.headline: Indian Tribe Wins Fight to Limit Research of Its DNA
articles.snippet: The Havasupai people, who live in the Grand Canyon, had claimed that university researchers misused their DNA.
articles.abstract: The Havasupai people, who live in the Grand Canyon, had claimed that university researchers misused their DNA.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUPAI, Ariz. — Seven years ago, the Havasupai Indians, who live amid the turquoise waterfalls and red cliffs miles deep in the Grand Canyon, issued a “banishment order” to keep Arizona State University employees from setting foot on their reservation — an ancient punishment for what they regarded as a genetic-era betrayal.

articles.headline: Goldman Executives Are Expected to Testify Before Senate Panel
articles.snippet: President Obama and the S.E.C.’s chairwoman defended the timing of the agency’s suit against the firm from critics who suggested the move was politically motivated.
articles.abstract: President Obama and the S.E.C.’s chairwoman defended the timing of the agency’s suit against the firm from critics who suggested the move was politically motivated.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government’s case against Goldman Sachs is about to get its first public airing, in what could be a gripping preview of the legal battle to come.

articles.headline: Tough Cameras Make Underwater Photography Easier
articles.snippet: Capture the fun beneath the waves or surfing with a new generation of cameras and camcorders, and they’re mostly non-smashable, too.
articles.abstract: Capture the fun beneath the waves or surfing with a new generation of cameras and camcorders, and they’re mostly non-smashable, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: When normal people hear that they’re going to the Bahamas, they think: “Bathing suit!” “Sunscreen!” “Flip-flops!”

articles.headline: At 40, Earth Day Is Now Big Business
articles.snippet: Many groups now accept money from corporations or are working with them to change social behavior.
articles.abstract: Many groups now accept money from corporations or are working with them to change social behavior.
articles.lead_paragraph: So strong was the antibusiness sentiment for the first Earth Day in 1970 that organizers took no money from corporations and held teach-ins “to challenge corporate and government leaders.”

articles.headline: Challenging China in Rare Earth Mining
articles.snippet: Molycorp Minerals is seeking to raise nearly $500 million to reopen a mine near Las Vegas that was once the world leader in rare earth elements, but success is not certain.
articles.abstract: Molycorp Minerals is seeking to raise nearly $500 million to reopen a mine near Las Vegas that was once the world leader in rare earth elements, but success is not certain.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a high plateau where burros and jackrabbits wander an hour’s drive southwest of Las Vegas, a 400-foot-deep chasm hewn from volcanic rock sits at the center of an international policy debate.

articles.headline: Ash Turns Routine Flights Into Overland Odysseys
articles.snippet: Airports rumbled back to life across Europe, but travelers who opted for land or sea journeys told of epic adventures.
articles.abstract: Airports rumbled back to life across Europe, but travelers who opted for land or sea journeys told of epic adventures.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — When President Toomas H. Ilves of Estonia arrived in Turkey last week, he had prepared for a state visit — one state visit. What he got, courtesy of an erupting volcano in Iceland, was more like a presidential road trip — nine countries in four days — evoking the sedate diplomacy of a bygone era.

articles.headline: Judicial Bouts Reveal Power of Persuasion
articles.snippet: Judge Diane P. Wood’s long relationship with conservative judges on the Seventh Circuit offers hints at what kind of Supreme Court justice she might be.
articles.abstract: Judge Diane P. Wood’s long relationship with conservative judges on the Seventh Circuit offers hints at what kind of Supreme Court justice she might be.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There were few liberals and just one woman on the federal appeals court in Chicago when Diane P. Wood, an antitrust expert with a flair for foreign language and an ear for playing the oboe, showed up in the summer of 1995. The chief judge, a scholarly conservative named Richard A. Posner, promptly gave her some advice.

articles.headline: Edging Back to Nuclear Power
articles.snippet: Much opposition to nuclear reactors has fallen away, but their revival is proceeding at a crawl.
articles.abstract: Much opposition to nuclear reactors has fallen away, but their revival is proceeding at a crawl.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR the first time since the 1970s, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has announced a step that it once took routinely: appointing an inspector for a new reactor construction project.

articles.headline: The New Jobs in Atomic Energy
articles.snippet: Seeking a stable, well-paying career, many young people have decided that the prospects for nuclear technicians are promising.
articles.abstract: Seeking a stable, well-paying career, many young people have decided that the prospects for nuclear technicians are promising.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOW often does a high school principal pull aside a college-bound student and suggest he attend a two-year community college instead? That’s just what happened to Brian Moreno, a standout math student in El Campo, Tex., who planned to enroll at Texas A&M.

articles.headline: Federal Reserve Made $47.4 Billion in 2009
articles.snippet: The transfer, a record sum, was the result of the central bank’s actions to support the fragile housing market.
articles.abstract: The transfer, a record sum, was the result of the central bank’s actions to support the fragile housing market.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve transferred $47.4 billion, a record sum, to the Treasury Department last year, a result of the central bank’s actions to support the fragile housing market.

articles.headline: For United, a Merger Still Looms
articles.snippet: The decision by US Airways suggested that Continental’s own discussions with United might succeed.
articles.abstract: The decision by US Airways suggested that Continental’s own discussions with United might succeed.
articles.lead_paragraph: The announcement by US Airways on Thursday that it was ending merger discussions with United Airlines clears the path for rival talks between Continental Airlines and United.
